>
> Hey Stephen,

> =
Great questions!  We'll have to think about some of them for awhile
> but h=
ere's a few answers:
> 
> The reason why I chose to use a separate output f=
or each connection
> layer instead of using a 3-dimensional CPPN is because=
 I wanted to
> separate the network for each layer.  If you use the 3-D CPP=
N 
method,
> then the two layers are only distinguished by the values of 'z=
'. 
> Because I'm only using two layers, I wanted to make sure that each
> =
layer did some unique processing.  If there was only one output, it
> would=
 be harder for the connection layers to distinguish themselves 
as
> they w=
ould be too dependent.  In the worst case, z1 and z2 inputs 
are
> not used=
 and the two layers are exactly the same. I haven't done any
> empirical te=
sts on which method is better so I do not have any
> evidence to back my cl=
aim, but it's my intuition.
> 
> I haven't tried any computer opponents oth=
er than Xcheckers.  I have
> had my friends and people in the lab play agai=
nst the HyperNEAT
> opponent and it is definitely better than all of us :-)=
.  I would 
like
> to release a binary version so people can play the oppon=
ents at
> different generations and see the change in performance.
> 
> One=
 active area of interest is to figure out how good a HyperNEAT
> player is =
in a global sense.  In Chellapilla & Fogel's paper, they
> played human opp=
onents in checkers on MSN Gaming Zone online and got
> an expert rating on =
that game server.  The problem with this is that
> it is very time consumin=
g to play games by hand. It would not be
> feasible for me to test several =
individuals in this way.
> 
> I have experimented with coevolution, but I n=
eed to solve the
> aforementioned problem before I can say anything about t=
he 
performance
> of the evolved individuals.
>
